difference between bruschetta and crostini?", "answerCount": 1, "acceptedAnswer": {"@type": "Answer", "text": "The biggest difference between the two is that <a href=\"https://www.skinnytaste.com/bruschetta-with-tomato-and-basil-1-ww/\">bruschetta</a> uses thicker sourdough bread, often rubbed with garlic and grilled. Crostini\u2019s signature bread is thinly sliced and toasted baguette. I cut my bread just a quarter-inch thick. So I found that 15mins was not enough baking time and baked them another 4 to 5 mins - checking always at the 2 min mark to insure they did not burn. The edges did come out nice and crisp but the centers, while soft, tasted underbaked - with a definite flour taste. I am not sure what I did wrong. If I had let them bake longer they would have burned. My husband is happy with them, although he asked me not to make them as sweet the next time. Unfortunately I am not as happy with their texture. Repeat this series, rotating round the bowl, until the dough starts to look like bread dough and comes together in more of a ball. This should take about a minute of going round the bowl 4 to 5 times pulling and tucking into the center. Let the dough rest, covered for 30 minutes. You will do this 3 more times every 30 minutes, covering after each time for a total of 2 hours, if time permits. If you don\u2019t have the time, you can do this twice, it will still turn out just fine.", "name": "Stretches and Folds: After the dough has rested 30 minutes, use a wet hand to gently pull the corner of the dough near the side of the bowl and push it down into the middle of the bowl. Repeat this series, rotating round the bowl, until the dough starts to look like bread dough and comes together in more of a ball. This should take about a minute of going round the bowl 4 to 5 times pulling and tucking into the center. Let the dough rest, covered for 30 minutes. You will do this 3 more times every 30 minutes, covering after each time for a total of 2 hours, if time permits. If you don\u2019t have the time, you can do this twice, it will still turn out just fine.", "url": "https://www.skinnytaste.com/sourdough-bread-recipe/#wprm-recipe-143470-step-0-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Rest (Bulk Fermentation):  After the series of stretches, cover the dough with a damp kitchen towel and a lid or plate so it doesn\u2019t dry out and let it rise for 6 to 7 hours at room temperature, or up to 8 to 9 hours in colder temps. This is known as the bulk rise. The dough is ready when it has increased by 50% to 70% volume, jiggles when you shake the bowl and has some scattered bubbles visible on the sides and top.", "name": "Rest (Bulk Fermentation):  After the series of stretches, cover the dough with a damp kitchen towel and a lid or plate so it doesn\u2019t dry out and let it rise for 6 to 7 hours at room temperature, or up to 8 to 9 hours in colder temps. This is known as the bulk rise. Remove the lid, lower the oven temp to 400\u00b0F and put the dutch oven back in the oven, uncovered, for another 20 to 30 minutes.
